docs.lead_paragraph: New guidelines issued by the American Cancer Society present yet another wrinkle for women who are trying to make informed decisions about their health care.
docs.abstract: Editorial warns new American Cancer Society guidelines that advocate women with average risk of breast cancer have mammograms at age 45 may be misleading; cites experts' conflicting recommendations on appropriate age for test and calls on insurers to keep covering women's mammograms from age 40.
docs.snippet: New guidelines issued by the American Cancer Society present yet another wrinkle for women who are trying to make informed decisions about their health care.

docs.lead_paragraph: The former Massachusetts governor should be proud of helping to pave the way for Obamacare, but in today’s Republican Party that is viewed as a crime.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column credits Mitt Romney with pioneering health reform which led to Obamacare; pities Romney for not being able to take credit for its success, for fear of offending Republican base.
docs.snippet: The former Massachusetts governor should be proud of helping to pave the way for Obamacare, but in today’s Republican Party that is viewed as a crime.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some officials blame the government’s actions for the shuttering of some of these start-ups created under the Affordable Care Act.

headline.main: Health Care Co-op Closings Narrow Consumers’ Choices
headline.print_headline: Health Care Co-op Closings Narrow Consumers’ Choices

docs.abstract: Eight alternative health insurers formed under Affordable Care Act are shutting down, leaving only 14 so-called co-op insurers left; about 500,000 customers are looking for health coverage for 2016, leaving them with fewer choices and possibly higher rates.
docs.snippet: Some officials blame the government’s actions for the shuttering of some of these start-ups created under the Affordable Care Act.

keywords.name: organizations

byline.original: By REED ABELSON and ABBY GOODNOUGH

docs.lead_paragraph: People with very low incomes are not usually required to file a tax return, but must do so to keep premium tax credits provided under the Affordable Care Act.

headline.main: Thousands Who Didn’t File Tax Returns May Lose Health Care Subsidies
headline.print_headline: Health Care Subsidies Are at Risk for Recipients Who Didn’t File Returns

docs.abstract: Recipients of health insurance subsidy who failed to file 2014 tax return, or filed late or incomplete return, violated federal rules and may face full cost of insurance in 2016; many of those at risk have incomes low enough they wouldn't normally have filed return, while others found supplementary form for reconciling Affordable Care Act tax credits too daunting.
docs.snippet: People with very low incomes are not usually required to file a tax return, but must do so to keep premium tax credits provided under the Affordable Care Act.

docs.lead_paragraph: A tax on expansive health plans would remove an incentive for employers to pay wages in the form of insurance. That could benefit the system over all.

headline.main: Uniting Behind the Divisive ‘Cadillac’ Tax on Health Plans
headline.print_headline: Uniting Behind a Divisive Health Tax

docs.abstract: Economic View column; the Upshot; Cadillac tax on expansive health insurance plans would remove incentive for employers to pay workers in health care, which drives up costs; resulting wage increases could be significant, with $45 billion potential in take-home pay by 2025.
docs.snippet: A tax on expansive health plans would remove an incentive for employers to pay wages in the form of insurance. That could benefit the system over all.
